Or here to open him.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: Do but behold me
If there be pity in you, do but view me,
But view the misery I have undertaken
For you the povertie.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He will come presently.
Now play your best Sir, though I loose this Rook here
Yet I get Libertie.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: I'le seize your fair hand
And warm it with a hundred, hundred kisses
The God of love warm your desires but equal
That shall play my game now.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What do you mean Sir?
Why do you stop me?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: That ye may intend me.
The time ha's blest us both: Love bids us use it.
I am a Gentleman nobly descended:
Young to invite your Love, rich to maintain it.
I bring a whole heart to ye, thus I give it,
And to those burning altars thus I offer,
And thus divine lips, where perpetuall Spring grows.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Take that, ye are too saucy.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: How proud Lady?
Strike my deserts?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I was too blame.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What wise, there?
Heaven keep my house from thieves.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: I am wretched:
Opened, discovered, lost to my wishes.
I shall be whooted at.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What noise was this (wife?)
Why dost thou smile?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: This proud thing will betray me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why these lie here? what anger (deare?)

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Why none, Sir,
Onely a chance, your pupill said he plaid well,
And so indeed he do's: he undertook for ye
Because I would not sit so long time idle
I made my Liberty avoided your mate,
And he again as cunningly endangered me,
Indeed he put me strangely to it. When presently
Hearing you come, and having broke his ambush too
Having the second time brought off my Queen fair,
I rose o'th' sudden smilingly to shew ye,
My apron caught the Chesse-board, and the men,
And there the noise was.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thou art grown a Master,
For all this, I shall beat ye.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: Or I, Lawyer,
For now I love her more, 'twas a neat answer,
And by it hangs a mighty hope, I thank her
She gave my pate a sound knock that it rings yet,
But you shall have a sounder if I live Lawyer,
My heart akes yet I would not be in that fear—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am glad ye are a gamester, Sir, sometimes
For recreation we two shall fight hard at it.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He will prove too hard for me,

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: I hope he shall do,
But your Ches-board is too hard for my head, line that good Lady,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I have been attoning two most wrangling neighbours,
They had no money, therefore I made even
Come, let's go in, and eat, truly I am hungry.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I have eaten already, I must intreat your pardon

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do as ye please, we shall expect ye at supper.
He ha's got a little heart, now it seems handsomly,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You'l get no little head, if I do not look to ye.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.l: If ever I do catch thee again thou vanity—

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I was too blame to be so rash, I am sorie— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Heare but my reasons,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O my patience heare 'em.
Can cunning falshood colour an excuse?
With any seeming shape of borrowed truth?
Extenuate this wofull wrong, not error.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: You gave consent that to defeat my brother
I should take any course,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But not to make
The cure more loathsome then the fowle disease:
Was't not enough you took me to your bed,
Tir'd with loose dalliance, and with emptie veines,
All those abilities spent before and wasted,
That could conferre the name of mother on me?
But that (to perfect my account of sorrow)
For my long barrennesse you must highten it
By shewing to my face, that you were fruitfull
Hug'd in the base embraces of another?
If Solitude that dwelt beneath my roofe,
And want of children was a torment to me
What end of my vexation to behold
A bastard to upbraid me with my wants?
And heare the name of father paid to ye
Yet know my self no mother,
What can I say?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: shall I confesse my fault and ask your pardon?
Will that content ye?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: If it could make void,
What is confirm'd in Court No, no, Don Henrique
You shall know that I find my self abus'd,
And adde to that I have a womans anger,
And while I look upon this Basilisk
Whose envious eyes hath blasted all my comforts
Rest confident I'le study my dark ends,
And not your pleasures,

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Noble Lady, heare me,
Not as my Fathers son, but as your servant,
Vouchsafe to heare me, for such in my duty,
I ever will appeare: And far be it from
My poore ambition, ever to looke on you,
But with that reverence; which a slave stands bound
To pay a worthy Mistris: I have heard
That Dames of highest place, nay Queenes themselves,
Disdaine not to be serv'd by such as are
Of meanest Birth: and I shall be most happie,
To be emploi'd when you please to command me
Even in the coursest Office, as your Page,
I can wayte on your trencher: fill your wine
Carry your pontafles, and be sometimes bless'd
In all humilitie to touch your feete
Or if that you esteeme that too much grace
I can run by your Coach: observe your lookes
And hope to gaine a fortune by my service,
With your good favour, which now, as a Son,
I dare not challenge

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: As a Son,

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Forgive me
I will forget the name, let it be death
For me to call you Mother.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Still upbraided?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: No way left to appease you?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: None: now heare me,
Heare what I vow before the face of heaven,
And if I breake it all plagues in this life,
And those that after death are fear'd, fall on me,
While that this Bastard staies under my rooffe,
Looke for no peace at home, for I renounce
All Offices of a wife,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: What am I falne to?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I will not eate, nor sleepe with you and those howres
Which I should spend in prayers for your health
Shall be emploi'd in Curses,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Terrible.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: All the day long, I'le be as tedious to you
As lingring fevers, and I'le watch the nights,
To ring alon'd your shame and breake your sleepes
Or if you doe but slumber, I'le appeare
In the shape of all my wrongs, and like a fury
Fright you to madnes, and if all this faile
To worke out my revenge, I have friends and kinsmen,
That will not sit downe tame with the disgrace
That's offer'd to our noble familie
In what I suffer,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: How am I devided
Betweene the duties I owe as a Husband,
And pietie of a Parent?

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: I am taught Sir
By the instinct of nature that obedience
Which bids me to prefer your peace of mind,
Before those pleasures that are dearest to me
Be wholy hers (my Lord) I quit all parts,
That I may challenge: may you grow old together
And no distast e're find you and before
The Characters of age are printed on you
May you see many Images of your selves,
Though I, like some false Glasse, that's never look'd in
Am cast a side, and broken from this hower
(Unles invited, which I dare not hope for)
I never will set my forbidden feete,
Over your threshold: onely give me leave
Though cast off to the world, to mention you,
In my devotions 'tis all I sue for
And so I take my last leave

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Though I am
Devoted to a wife nay allmost sol'd
A slave to serve her pleasures, yet I cannot
So part with all humanity, but I must
Shew something of a Father: thou shalt not goe
Unfurnish'd and unfriended too: take that
To guard thee from necessities; may thy goodnes
Meet many favours, and thine innocence
Deserve to be the heire of greater fortunes,
Then thou wer't borne to. Scorne me not Violante
This banishment is a kind of civill death,
And now, as it were at his Funerall
To shed a teare or two, is not unmanly
And so farewell for ever: one word more,
Though I must never see thee (my Ascanio)
When this is spent (for so the Judge decreed)
Send to me for supply: are you pleas'd now?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Yes: I have cause: to see you howle and blubber
At the parting of my torment, & your shame Bed ready, wine, table Standish & Paper.
'Tis well: proceed: supply his wants: doe doe:
Let the great dowre I brought serve to maintain
Your Bastards riots: send my Clothes and Jewells,
To your old acquaintance, your deare dame his Mother
Now you begin to melt, I know 'twill follow,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Is all I doe misconstrude?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I will take
A course to right my selfe a speeding one:
By the bless'd Saints, I will; if I prove cruell
The shame to see thy foolish pitty taught me
To loose my naturall softnes, keepe off from me
Thy flateries are infectious, and I'le fle thee
As I would doe a Leaper.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Let not fury
Transport you so: you know I am your Creature,
All love, but to your self, with him, hath left me
I'le ioyne with you in any thing

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: In vaine
I'le take mine owne waies, and will have no partners,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I will not crosse you,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Doe not, they shall find
That to a Woman of her hopes beguil'd
A viper troad on, or an Aspick's, mild. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Sits the game there? I have you by mine order,
I love Leandro for't

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: But you must shew it
In lending him your helpe, to gain him meanes
And opportunitie.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He shall want nothing,
I know my Advocate to a hayre, and what
Will fetch him from his prayers, if he use any,
I am honyed with the project: I would have him horn'd
For a most pretious Beast.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: But you loose time;

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I am gon, instruct you Diego, you will find him
A sharpe and subtle knave, give him but hints
And he will amplifie: Se all things ready
I'll fetch him with a vengeance.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: If he faile now,
Wee'll give him over too,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Tush he is flesh'd,
And knowes what vaine to strike for his owne credit.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: All things are ready.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Then we shall have a merry Scene, no're feare it.

div.head: Scena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Amaranta (with a note) and Moore.

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: Is thy Master gone out?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Even now, the Curat fetch'd him,
About a serious businesse as it seem'd,
For he snatch'd up his Cloak, and brush'd his hat strait,
Set his Band handsomely, and out he gallop'd.

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: 'Tis well, 'tis very well, he went out (Egla.)
As luckily, as one would say, goe Husband,
He was call'd by providence: fling this short paper
Into Leandro's Cell, and waken him,
He is monstrous vexed, and musty, at my Chesse-play;
But this shall supple him, when he has read it:
Take your owne recreation for two houres,
And hinder nothing.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: If I doe, I'll hang for't. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If that you lov'd Ascanio for himselfe,
And not your private ends, you rather should
Blesse the faire opportunitie, that restores him
To his Birth-right, and the Honours he was borne to,
Then grieve at his good Fortune.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Grieve Octavio?
I would resigne my Essence, that he were
As happy as my love could fashion him,
Though every blessing that should fall on him,
Might prove a curse to me, my sorrow springs
Out of my feare, and doubt he is not safe.
I am acquainted with Don Henrique's nature,
And I have heard too much the fiery temper
Of Madam Violante: can you thinke
That she, that almost is at war with heaven
For being barren, will with equall eyes
Behold a Son of mine?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: His Fathers care,
That for the want of Issue tooke him home,
(Though with the forfeiture of his owne fame)
Will looke unto his safetie.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Step-mothers
Have many eyes, to find a way to mischiefe,
Though blind to goodnesse.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Here comes Don Jamy,
And with him our Ascanio.

sp.speaker: Jamy.
sp.l: Good youth leave me,
I know thou art forbid my company,
And onely to be seene with me, will call on
Thy Fathers anger.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Sir if that to serve you
Could loose me any thing (as indeed it cannot)
I still would follow you. Alas I was borne
To doe you hurt but not to help my selfe,
I was, for some particular end, tooke home,
But am cast off againe.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: The Lady, whom my Father calls his wife
Abhors my sight, is sick of me, and forc'd him
To turne me out of dores.

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: By my best hopes
I thanke her crueltie, for it comes neere
A saving charitie.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: I am onely happy
That yet I can relieve you, 'pray you share:
My Father's wondrous kind, and promises
That I should be supplide: but sure the Lady
Is a malitious woman, and I feare
Meanes me no good.

sp.speaker: Iamy.
sp.l: I am turn'd a stone with wonder,
And know not what to thinke.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: From my Lady,
Your private eare and this—

sp.speaker: Iamy.
sp.l: New Miracles?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: She sayes, if you dare make your selfe a Fortune,
She will propose the meanes; My Lord Don Henrique
Is now from home and she alone expects you,
If you dare trust her so, if not despaire of
A second offer, Exit.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Though there were an Ambush
Layd for my life, I, ll on and sound this secret,
Retire thee (my Ascanio) with thy Mother:
But stir not forth, some great designe's on foot,
Fall what can fall, if e're the Sun be set,
I see you not, give me dead.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: We will expect you,
And those bless'd Angels, that love goodnesse, guard you.

div.head: Scena Quinta.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Is't possible he should be rich?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Most possible,
He hath bin long, though he had but little gettings,
Drawing together, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Accounted a poore Sexton,
Honest poore Diego,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I assure ye, a close Fellow,
Both close, and scraping, and that fills the bags, Sir,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A notable good Fellow too?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Sometimes, Sir, Diego ready in Bed, wine, cup.
When he hop'd to drink a man into a surfeit,
That he might gaine by his Grave.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So many thousands?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Heaven knowes what.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Tis strange,
Tis very strange; but we see by endeavour,
And honest labour—

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Milo by continuance
Grew from a silly Calfe (with your worships reverence)
To carry a Bull, from a penny, to a pound, Sir,
And from a pound, to many: 'tis the progresse.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ye say true, but he lov'd to feed well also,
And that me-thinks—

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: From another mans Trencher, Sir,
And there he found it season'd with small charge:
There he would play the Tyrant, and would devoure ye
More then the Graves he made, at home he liv'd
Like a Camelion suckt th'Ayre of misery, Table out Standish paper, stools.
And grew fat by th'Brewis of an Eg-shel,
Would smell a Cooks shop, and goe home and surfeit,
And be a moneth in fasting out that Fever.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: These are good Symptomes: do's he lye so sick say ye?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Oh, very sick.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And chosen me Executor?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Onely your Worship.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No hope of his amendment?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: None, that we find.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He hath no kinsmen neither?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: 'Truth, very few.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: His mind will be the quieter,
What Doctors has he?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: There's none sir he believes in.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They are but needlesse things, in such extremities.
Who drawes the good-man's will?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Marry that doe I, Sir.
And to my griefe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Griefe will doe little now, Sir,
Draw it to your comfort, Friend, and as I counsell ye,
An honest man, but such men live not alwayes
Who are about him?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Many now he is passing,
That would pretend to his love, yes, and some gentlemen
That would faine counsell him, and be of his kindred;
Rich men can want no heires, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They doe ill,
Indeed they doe, to trouble him: very ill, Sir,
But we shall take a care.

div.stage: Enter Diego (in a Bed) Millanes, Arsenio, and Parishioners.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Will ye come neare, Sir,
'Pray ye bring him out; Now ye may see in what state:
Give him fresh ayre. Bed thrust out.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am sorry, Neighbour Diego,
To find ye in so weake a state.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Ye are welcome,
But I am fleeting, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Me-thinkes he looks well,
His colour fresh, and strong, his eyes are chearfull.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A glimmering before death, 'tis nothing els Sir,
Do you see how he fumbles with the sheet? do ye note that

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: My learned Sir 'pray ye sit: I am bold to send for ye,
To take a care of what I leave.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Doe you heare that?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Play the knave finely.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: So I will, I warrant ye,
And carefully.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Pray ye doe not trouble him,
You see he's weake and has a wandring fancie.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: My honest Neighbours, weep not, I must leave ye,
I cannot alwayes beare ye company,
We must drop still, there is no remedie:
'Pray ye Master Curat, will ye write my Testament,
And write it largely it may be remembred
And be witnesse to my Legacies good Gentlemen;
Your worship I doe make my full Executor,
You are a man of wit and understanding:
Give me a cup of wine to raise my Spirits,
For I speake low: I would before these Neighbours
Have ye to sweare (Sir) that you will see it executed,
And what I give, let equally be rendred
For my soules health.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I vow it truly, Neighbours,
Let not that trouble ye before all these,
Once more I give my Oath.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Then set me higher,
And pray ye come neare me all.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: We are ready for ye.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Now spur the Asse, and get our friend time.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: First then,
After I have given my Body to the wormes
(For they must be serv'd first, they are seldome cozen'd)

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Remember your Parish, Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: You speake truly,
I doe remember it, a lewd vile Parish,
And pray it may be mended: To the Poore of it,
(Which is to all the Parish) I give nothing,
For nothing, unto nothing, is most naturall,
Yet leave as much space, as will build an Hospitall,
Their children may pray for me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What doe you give to it?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Set downe two thousand Duckets,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Tis a good gift,
And will be long remembred.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: To your worship,
(Because you must take paines to see all finish'd)
I give two thousand more, it may be three, Sir,
A poore gratuitie for your paines-taking.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: These are large summes;

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Nothing to him that has 'em.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: To my old Master Vicar, I give five hundred,
(Five hundred, and five hundred, are too few Sir)
But there be more to serve.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This fellow coynes sure.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Give me some more drink. Pray ye buy Books, buy Books,
You have a learned head, stuffe it with Libraries,
And understand 'em, when ye have done, 'tis Justice,
Run not the Parish mad with Controversies,
Nor preach not Abstinence to longing women,
'Twill budge the bottoms of their consciences:
I would give the Church new Organs, but I prophecie
The Church-wardens would quickly pipe'em out o'th' Parish,
Two hundred Duckets more to mend the chancel,
And to paint true Orthographie, as many,
They write Sunt with a C, which is abominable,
'Pray you set that downe, to poore Maidens marriages.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I that's wel thought of, what's your wil in that point?
A meritorious thing.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No end of this will?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I give per annum two hundred ells of Lockram,
That there be no strait dealings in their Linnens,
But the Sayles cut according to their Burthens;
To all Bell-Ringers, I bequeath new Ropes,
And let them use 'em at their owne discretions.

sp.speaker: Ars
sp.l: You may remember us.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I doe, good Gentlemen,
And I bequeath ye both good carefull Surgeons
A Legacy, you have need of, more then money,
I know you want good Diets and good Lotions,
And in your pleasures good take heed.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He raves now.
But 'twill be quickly off,

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I doe bequeath ye
Commodities of pins: browne papers: pack-threds,
Rost porke & puddings: Ginger-bread, & Jewes-trumps,
Of penny Pipes, and mouldy Pepper: take 'em,
Take 'em even where you please, and be cozen'd with 'em,
I should bequeath ye Executions also,
But those I'll leave to th'Law.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Now he growes temperate.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You will give no more?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: I am loth to give more from ye,
Because I know you will have a care to execute
Onely, to pious uses, Sir, a little.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: If he be worth all these, I am made for ever,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I give to fatall Dames, that spin mens threds out,
And poore distressed Damsells, that are militant
As members of our owne Afflictions,
A hundred Crowns to buy warm tubbs to worke in,
I give five hundred pounds to buy a Church-yard,
A spacious Church-yard, to lay Theeves and knaves in,
Rich men, and honest men, take all the roome up.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Are ye not weary?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Never of well-doing.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: These are mad Legacies.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: They were got as madly;
My Sheep, and Oxen, and my moveables,
My Plate, and Jewells, and five hundred Acres;
I have no heires.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This cannot be, 'tis Monstrous.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Three Ships at Sea too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You have made me full Executor.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Full, full, and totall, would I had more to give ye
But these may serve an honest mind.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ye say true,
A very honest mind, and make it rich too;
Rich, wondrous rich, but where shall I raise these monys,
About your house? I see no such great promises;
Where shall I find these summes?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Even where you please Sir,
You are wise and provident and know businesse
Ev'n raise 'em where you shal think good, I am reasonable

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thinke good? will that raise thousands?
What doe you make me?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: You have sworn to see it done, that's all my comfort.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Where I please? this is pack'd sure to disgrace me.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Ye are just and honest, and I know you will doe it,
Ev'n where you please, for you know where the wealth is.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am abused, betrayed, I am laugh'd at, scorn'd,
Baffel'd, and boared, it seemes.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: No, no, ye are fooled.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Most finely fooled, and handsomely, and neatly,
Such cunning Masters must be fooled sometimes, Sir,
And have their worships noses wiped, 'tis healthfull,
We are but quit: you foole us of our moneys
In every Cause, in every Quiddit wipe us.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha ha, some more drink, for my heart, Gentlemen,
This merry Lawyer— ha, ha, ha, ha this Scholler—
I thinke this fitt will cure me: this Executor—
I shall laugh out my Lungs.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This is derision above sufferance, villany
Plotted, and set against me.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Faith 'tis knavery,
In troth I must confesse, thou art fooled indeed, Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Did you thinke, had this man been rich—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Tis well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: He would have chosen such a Wolfe, a Cancker,
A Maggot-pate, to be his whole Executor.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A Lawyer, that entangles all mens honesties,
And lives like a Spider in a Cobweb lurking,
And catching at all Flies, that passe his pitt-falls?
Puts powder to all States, to make em caper?
Would he trust you?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Doe you deserve? I find, Gentlemen,
This Cataplasme of a well cozen'd Lawyer
Laid to my stomach lenifies my Fever,
Me-thinkes I could eat now and walke a little.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am asham'd to feele how flat I am cheated,
How grossely, and malitiously made a May-game,
A damned Trick; my wife, my wife, some Rascall:
My credit, and my wife, some lustfull villaine,
Some Bawd, some Rogue,

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Some craftie Foole has found ye:
This 'tis Sir, to teach ye to be too busie,
To covet all the gaines, and all the rumours
To have a stirring oare, in all mens actions.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: We did this, but to vex your fine officiousnesse.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Good 'yeild ye and go'd thank ye: I am fooled, gentlemen;
The Lawyer is an Asse, I doe confesse it,
A weak dull shallow Asse: good even to your worships:
Vicar, remember Vicar, Rascall remember,
Thou notable rich Rascall.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I doe remember, Sir,
'Pray ye stay a little, I have ev'n two Legacies
To make your mouth up, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Remember Varletts,
Quake & remember, Rogues; I have brine for your Buttocks. Ex.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Oh how he frets, and fumes now like a dunghill.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: His gall containes fine stuffe now to make poysons,
Rare damned stuffe.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Let's after him, and still vex him,
And take my Friend off: by this time he has prosper'd,
He cannot loose this deere time: 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Well Diego, thou hast done.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Hast done it daintily.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: And shalt be as well paid, Boy—

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Goe, let's crucifie him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I have told ye all my story, and how desperately.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I doe believe: let's walke on, time is pretious,
Not to be spent in words, here no more wooing,
The open Ayre's an enemy to Lovers, Pewter ready for noyse.
Doe as I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I'll doe any thing,
I am so over-joy'd, I'll fly to serve ye.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Take your joy moderately, as it is ministred,
And as the cause invites: that man's a foole
That at the sight o'th' Bond, dances and leapes,
Then is the true joy, when the money comes.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: You cannot now deny me.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Nay, you know not,
Women have crotchets, and strange fits.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: You shall not.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Hold ye to that and sweare it confidently,
Then I shall make a scruple to deny ye:
'Pray ye let's step in, and see a friend of mine,
The weather's sharp: we'll stay but halfe an houre,
We may be miss'd els: a private fine house 'tis, Sir,
And we may find many good welcomes.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: Doe Lady,
Doe happy Lady.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: All your mind's of doing,
You must be modester.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I will be any thing.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Open the dores, and give me roome to chafe in
Mine owne roome, and my liberty: why Maid there,
Open, I say, and doe not anger me,
I am subject to much fury: when ye dish-clout?
When doe ye come? a sleepe, ye lazie hell-hound?
Nothing intended, but your ease, and eating?
No body here? why wife, why wife? why jewell?
No tongue to answer me? 'pre'thee (good Pupill)
Dispence a little with thy carefull study,
And step to th' doore, and let me in; nor he neither?
Ha! not at's study? nor asleepe? nor no-body?
I'll make ye heare: the house of Ignorance,
No sound inhabits here: I have a key yet
That commands all: I feare I am metamorphiz'd.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He keepes his fury still, and may doe mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: He shalbe hang'd first, we'll be sticklers there, boyes

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: The hundred thousand Dreams now, that posses him
Of jealousie, and of revenge, and frailtie
Of drawing Bills against us, and Petitions.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: And casting what his credit shall recover.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Let him cast till his Maw come up, we care not.
You shall be still secured. A great noyse within.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: We'll pay him home then;
Hark what a noyse he keeps within?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Certaine
H'as set his Chimneys o' fire, or the divell roars there.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: The Codixes o'th' Law are broke loose, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: He's fighting sure,

sp.speaker: Di
sp.l: I'll tell ye that immediatly— Exit.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Or doing some strange out-rage on himselfe.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Hang him, he dares not be so valiant.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: There's no body at home and he chafes like a Lyon,
And stinkes withall. Noyse still.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: No body?

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Not a creature,
Nothing within, but he and his Law-tempest,
The Ladies, dishes, kettles, how they fly all?
And how the Glasses through the Roomes?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: My friend sure
Has got her out and now he has made an end on't.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: See where the Sea comes? how it foams, & brussels?
The great Leviathan o'th' Law, how it tumbles?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Made every way an Asse? abus'd on all sides?
And from all quarters, people come to laugh at me?
Rise like a Comet, to be wonder'd at?
A horrid Comet, for Boyes tongues, and Ballads?
I will run from my wits.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Doe, doe, (good Lawyer)
And from thy money too, then thou wilt be quiet.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Here she comes home: now mark the salutations;
How like an Asse my friend goes?

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: She has pull'd his eares downe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Now, what sweet voyage? to what Garden, Lady?
Or to what Cosens house?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Is this my welcome?
I cannot goe to Church but thus I am scandall'd,
Use no devotion for my soule, but Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: To Church?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Yes, and ye keep sweet youths to wait upon me,
Sweet bred-up youths, to be a credit to me.
There's your delight againe, pray take him to ye,
However comes neare me more to debase me.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: How's this? how's this? good wife, how has he wrongd ye?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I was faine to drive him like a sheep before me,
I blush to thinke how people fleere, and scorn'd me,
Others have handsome men, that know behaviour,
Place, and observance: this silly thing knowes nothing,
Cannot tell ten; Let every Rascall justle me,
And still I push'd him on as he had bin comming.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ha! did ye push him on? is he so stupid?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: When others were attentive to the Priest,
Good devout Gentleman, then fell he fast
Fast, sound asleepe: then first began the Bag-pipes
The severall stops on's nose, made a rare musick,
A rare and lowd, and those plaid many an Antheme
Put out of that, he fell strait into dreaming.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: As cunning, as she is sweet; I like this carriage.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What did he then?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Why then he talked in his Sleep too,
Nay I'll divulge your morall vertues (sheeps-face)
And talk'd aloude, that every eare was fixt to him:
Did not I suffer (doe you thinke) in this time?
Talk of your bawling Law, of appellations
Of Declarations, and Excommunications:
Warrants, and Executions: and such divells
That drove all the Gentlemen out o'th' Church, by hurryes
With execrable oaths, they would never come there again
Thus am I serv'd, and man'd.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I pray ye forgive me,
I must confesse I am not fit to wait upon ye:
Alas, I was brought up—

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: To be an Asse,
A Lawyers Asse, to carry Bookes, and Buckrams.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: But what did you at Church?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: At Church, did ye aske her?
Doe you heare gentlemen, doe you mark that question?
Because you are halfe an heretique your selfe, Sir,
Would ye breed her too? this shall to the Inquisition,
A pious Gentlewoman, reprov'd for praying?
I'll see this filed, and you shall heare further, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Ye have an ill heart.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: It shall be found out Gentlemen,
There be those youths will search it.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: You are warme Signiour,
But a Faggot will warme ye better: we are witnesses.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Enough to hang him, doe not doubt.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Nay certaine,
I doe beleeve has rather no Religion.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: That must be knowne too, because shee goes to Church, sir?
O monstrum informe ingens!

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Let him goe on, sir,
His wealth will build a Nunnery, a faire one,
And this good Lady, when he is hang'd, and rotten,
May there be Abbesse.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You are cozend, honest Gentlemen,
I doe not forbid the use, but the forme, marke me.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Forme? what doe ye make of Forme?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They will undoe me,
Sweare, as I oft have done, and so betray me;
I must make faire way, and hereafter, Wife,
You are welcome home, & henceforth take your pleasure,
Goe, when ye shall thinke fit, I will not hinder ye,
My eyes are open now, and I see my errour,
My shame as great as that, but I must hide it.
The whole conveyance now I smell, but Basta,
Another time must serve: you see us friends, now
Heartily friends and no more chiding (gentlemen)
I have bin too foolish, I confesse, no more words,
No more (sweet wife.)

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You know my easie nature

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Goe get ye in: you see she has bin angry:
Forbeare her sight a while and time will pacify.
And learne to be more bold.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I would I could,
I will doe all I am able. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Doe Leandro,
We will not part, but friends of all hands.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Well said,
Now ye are reasonable, we can looke on ye,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ye have ierckt me: but for all that I forgive ye
Forgive ye hartily, and doe invite ye
To morrow to a Breakfast, I make but seldome
But now we will be merry.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Now ye are friendly,
Your doggednes and nigardize flung from ye.
And now we will come to ye

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Give me your hands, all;
You shall be wellcome hartily.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: We will be,
For wee'll eate hard

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The harder, the more wellcome,
And till the morning farewell; I have busines. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Farewell good bountiful Bartolus 'tis a brave wench
A sudaine witty Theif, and worth all service:
Goe wee'll all goe, and crucifie the Lawyer,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I'll clap foure tire of teeth into my mouth more
But I will grind his substance.

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: Well Leandro,
Thou hast had a strange voyage, but I hope
Thou rid'st now in safe harbour,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Lets goe drinke, Friends,
And laugh alou'd at all our merry may-games

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A match, a match 'twill whet our stomachs better.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Madam hees come. Chaire and stooles out.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Tis well how did he looke,
When he knew from whom you were sent? was he not startled?
Or confident? or fearefull?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: As appear'd
Like one that knew his fortune at the worst,
And car'd not what could follow.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Tis the better
Reach me a Chaire: So bring him in, be carefull
That none disturb us: I will try his temper,
And if I find him apt for my employments,
I'll worke him to my ends, if not I shall
Find other Engines.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Ther's my Ladie,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Leave us

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: You sent for me?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I did, and do's the favour,
Your present state considered, and my power,
Deserve no greater Ceremonie?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Ceremonie?
I use to pay that, where I doe owe dutie,
Not to my Brothers wife: I cannot fawne,
If you expect it from me, you are cozen'd,
And so farewell.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: He beares up still; I like it,
Pray you a word

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Yes: I will give you hearing
On equall termes, and sit by you as a friend,
But not stand as a Sutour: Now your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You are very bold.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: 'Tis fitt: since you are proud
I was not made to feed that foolish humour,
With flattery and observance

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Yet, with your favour,
A little forme ioyn'd with respect to her,
That can add to your wants, or free you from 'em
(Nay raise you to a fate, beyond your hopes) A Table ready covered with Cloath Napkins Salt Trenchers and Bread.
Might well become your wisedome,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: It would rather
Write me a Foole, should I but onely think
That any good to me, could flow from you,
Whom for so many yeares: I have found and prov'd
My greatest Enemy: I am still the same
My wants have not transform'd me: I dare tell you,
To your new cerviz'd face, what I have spoken
Freely behind your back, what I thinke of you,
You are the proudest thing, and have the least,
Reason to be so, that I ever read of
In stature you are a Giantesse: and your Tailour
Takes measure of you, with a Iacobs staffe,
Or he can never reach you, this by the way
For your large size: Now, in a word, or two
To treat of your Complexion were decorum:
You are so far from faire, I doubt your Mother
Was too familliar with the Moore, that serv'd her,
Your Limbes and Features, I passe breifely over,
As things not worth description; and come roundly
To your soule, if you have any: for 'tis doubtfull

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I laugh at this, proceed

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: This Soule, I speake of
Or rather salt to keepe this heape of flesh,
From being a walking stench, like a large Inne,
Stands open for the entertainement of
All impious practises: but ther's no Corner
An honest thought can take up: and as it were not
Sufficient in your self to comprehend
All wicked plots, you have taught the Foole, my Brother
By your contagion, almost to put off
The nature of the man, and turn'd him Devill
Because he should be like you, and I hope
Will march to hell together: I have spoken,
And if the limming you, in your true Colours
Can make the Painter gracious, I stand readie
For my reward, or if my words distaste you
I weigh it not, for though your Groomes were ready
To cut my throat for't, be assur'd I cannot
Use other Language

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You thinke you have said now,
Like a brave fellow: in this Womans War
You ever have bin train'd: spoke big: but suffer'd
Like a tame Asse; and when most spur'd and gall'd
Were never Master of the Spleene or Spirit,
That could raise up the anger of a man,
And force it into action,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Yes vile Creature
Wer't thou a subject worthy of my Sword,
Or that thy death, this moment, could call home,
My banish'd hopes, thou now wer't dead: dead (woman)
But being as thou art, it is sufficient
I scorne thee, and contemne thee

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: This shewes nobly:
I must confesse it: I am taken with it
For had you kneeld, and whind and shew'd a base
And low deiected mind, I had despis'd you
This Bravery (in your adverse fortune) conquers
And do's command me, and upon the sudaine
I feele a kind of pittie, growing in me,
For your misfortunes, pittie some sayes the Parent,
Of future love, and I repent my part,
So far in what you have suffered, that I could,
(But you are cold) doe something to repaire
What your base Brother (such Iami I thinke him)
Hath brought to ruine

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Be not amaz'd,
Our injuries are equall in his Bastard
You are familliar with what I grone for
And though the name of Husband holds a tye
Beyond a Brother, I, a poore weake Woman,
Am sensible, and tender of a wrong,
And to revenge it, would break through all letts,
That durst oppose me.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: By this kisse: start not: thus much, as a stranger
You may take from me; But, if you were pleas'd,
I should select you, as a bosome Friend,
I would print 'em, thus, and thus,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Keepe off.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Come neare,
Neere into the Cabinet of my Counsailes:
Simplicity and patience dwell with Fooles,
And let them beare those burthens, which wise men
Boldly shake off; Be mine and ioyne with me,
And when that I have rais'd you to a fortune,
(Doe not deny your selfe the happie meanes)
You'l looke on me, with more iudicious eies
And sweare I am most faire,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: What would this Woman?
The purpose of these words? speake not in ridles
And when I understand what you would counsell,
My answer shall be suddaine,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Thus then Iami,
The objects of our fury, are the same,
For young Ascanio, whom you snake like hug'd
(Frozen with wants to death) in your warme bosome,
Lives to supplant you in your certaine hopes,
And kills in me all comfort.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Now 'tis plaine,
I apprehend you: and were he remov'd—

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You, once againe were the undoubted heire.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: 'Tis not to be denyed; I was ice before,
But now ye have fir'd me,—

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I'l add fuell to it,
And by a nearer cut, doe you but steere
As I direct you bring our Bark into
The Port of happines,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: By Henriques death:
But you'l say hee's your Brother; in great fortunes
(Which are epitomes of States & Kingdomes) Dishes covered with papers in each ready.
The politicke brooke no Rivalls.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Excellent.
For sure I thinke out of a scrupulous feare,
To feed in expectation when I may
(Dispensing but a little with my conscience)
Come into full possession, would not argue
One that desir'd to thrive,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Now you speake like
A man that knowes the World.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: I needs must learne
That have so good a Tutresse: And what thinke you,
(Don Henrique and Ascanio cut off)
That none may live, that shall desire to trace us
In our black pathes, if that Octavio
His foster Father 'and the sad Iacinta,
(Faith pittie her, and free her from her Sorrowes)
Should fall Companions with 'em? When we are red
With murther, let us often bath in blood,
The collour will be scarlet.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And that's glorious,
And will protect the fact

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Suppose this don:
(If undiscovered) we may get for money,
(As that you know buyes any thing in Rome)
A dispensation

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And be married?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: True.
Or if it be knowne, trusse up our Gold and Jewells,
And fly to some free State, and there with scorne—

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Laugh at the lawes of Spaine.
'Twere admirable.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: We shall beget rare Children. I am rap'd with
The meere imagination—

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Shall it be don?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Shall? tis too tedious: furnish me with meanes
To hire the instruments, and to your self,
Say it is done already: I will shew you,
'Ere the Sun set, how much you have wrought upon me,
Your province is onely to use some meanes,
To send my Brother, to the Grove that's neighbour,
To the west Port of th' Citie; leave the rest,
To my owne practise; I have talk'd too long:
But now will doe: this kisse, with my Confession,
To worke a fell revenge: A mans a foole,
If not instructed in a Womans Schoole. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Bartolus Algazeirs and a Paratour. The Table set out and stooles.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You are well enough disguiz'd, furnish the Table,
Make no shew, what ye are, till I discover
Not a soule knowes ye here: be quick and dilligent,
These youthes, I have invited to a Breakefast,
But what the Sawce will be, I am of opinion
I shall take off the edges of their Appetites,
And greaze their gums, for eating hartily;
This month or two they have plaid their prizes with me
And with their severall flurts they have lighted dangerously
But sure I shall be quit: I heare 'em comming
Goe off, and wait the bringing in your service,
And doe it handsomely: you know where to have it
Wellcome i'Faith,

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: That's well said, honest Lawyer,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Said like a Neighbour

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Wellcome all: all over
And let's be merry:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: To that end we came Sir,
An hower of freedome's worth an age of juglings,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I am come too Sir, to specifie my Stomach
A poore reteyner to your worships bountie,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And thou shalt have it fill'd, my merry Diego,
My liberall, and my bonney bounteous Diego
Even filed till it groane againe

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Let it have faire play,
And if it founder then—
I'll tell ye neighbours,
Though I were angry yesterday, with ye all,
And very angry for me thought ye bobd me.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: No, no, by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, when I considered
It was a jest, and carried off so quaintly
It made me merry: very merry, Gentlemen,
I doe confes I could not sleepe to thinke on't
The mirth so tickled me, I could not slumber,

sp.speaker: Lop,
sp.l: Good mirth do's worke so: honest mirth,
Now, should we have meant in earnest—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You say true Neighbour,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: It might have bred such a distast and sowrenesse,
Such fond imaginations in your Braines, Sir
For things thrust home in earnest—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Very certaine
But I know ye all for merry waggs, and ere long
You shall know me too. in another fashion
Though y'are pamper'd ye shall beare part 'oth burthen.
Come Wife; Come bid 'em wellcome; Come my Jewell:
And Pupill, you shall come too; nere hang backward,
Come, come the woman's pleas'd, her anger's over,
Come, be not bashfull,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What do's he prepare here?
Sure ther's no meate 'ith house at least none drest,
Do's he meane to mock 'em? or some new bred Crotchet
Come o're his braines; I doe not like his kindnes?
But silence best becomes me: if he meane foule play
Sure they are enough to right themselves and let 'em,
I'll sit by, so they beat him not to powder,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Bring in the meate there, ha? Sit downe deare Neighbour
A little meate needs little Complement,
Sit downe I say:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What doe you meane by this Sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Convay away their weapons handsomely,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You know ther's none ith' house to answer ye,
But the poore Girle; you know ther's no meat neither

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Peace and be quiet; I shall make you smoak els
Ther's men and Meate enough, set it downe formally

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I feare some lew'd tricke, yet I dare not speake on't

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I have no dainties for ye Gentlemen,
Nor lodes of meat, to make the roome smell of'em
Onely a dish to every man I have dedicated,
And if I have pleas'd his appetite,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: O, a Capon,
A Bird of grace, and be thy will, I honour it

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: For me some fortie pound of lovely Beeffe,
Plac'd in a mediterranean sea of Brewisse

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Fall to, fall to that we may drinke and laugh after
Wait diligently knaves,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: What rare bits this?
An execution, blesse me!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nay take it to ye
Ther's no avoiding it 'tis somewhat tough Sir,
But a good stomach will endure it easely
The sum is, but a thousand duckets Sir,

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: A Capias from my Surgeon, and my Silke man,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Your carefull makers, but they have mard your diet
Stir not, your Swords are gon: ther's no avoiding me
And these are Algazeirs, doe you heare that passing bell?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A strong Citation, blesse me!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Out with your Beads, Curat,
The devills in your dish: bell, booke, and Candell,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A warrant to appeare before the Judges?
I must needs rise, and turne to'th wall.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ye need not,
Your feare I hope will make ye find your Breeches,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are betraid

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Invited, doe not wrong me,
Fall to, good Guests, you have dilligent men about ye,
Ye shall want nothing, that may persecute ye
These will not see ye start; Have I now found ye
Have I requited ye? You fool'd the Lawyer,
And thought it meritorious, to abuse him,
A thick ram headed knave: you rid, you spurd him,
And glorified your witts, the more ye wrongd him;
Within this hower, ye shall have all your Creditours,
A second dish of new debts, come upon ye,
And new invitements to the whip (Don Diego)
And Excommunications for the Learned Curat,
A Masque of all your furies shall dance to ye,

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: You dare not use us thus?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You shall be bobd (Gentlemen)
Stir, and as I have a life, ye goe to prison
To prison, without pittie instantly
Before ye speake another word to prison.
I have a better Guard, without, that waytes;
Doe you see this man, Don Curat? 'tis a Paratour
That comes to tell ye a delightfull story.
Of an old whore, ye have and then to teach ye
What is the penaltie; Laugh at me now Sir,
What Legacie would ye bequeath me now,
(And pay it on the naile?) to fly my fury?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: O gentle Sir,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do'st thou hope I will be gentle,
Thou foolish unconsiderate Curat?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Let me goe Sir,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll see thee hang first.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: And as I am a true Vicar,
Hark in your eare, hark softly—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, no bribery.
I'll have my swindge upon thee; Sirha? Rascall?
You lenten Chaps, you that lay sick, and mockt me,
Mockt me, abhominably; abused me lewdly
I'll make thee sick at heart, before I leave thee,
And groane, and dye indeed, and be worth nothing
Not worth a blessing, nor a Bell to knell for thee,
A sheete to cover thee, but that thou stealest,
Stealest from the Merchant, and the Ring he was buried with
Stealest from his Grave, doe you smell me now?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Have mercy on me!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No Psalme of mercy shall hold me from hanging thee
How do ye like your Breakfast? 'tis but short, Gentlemen
But sweet and healthfull; Your punishment, and yours, Sir
For some neare reasons, that concernes my Credit,
I will take to my self.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Doe Sir, and spare not
I have bin too good a wife, and too obedient,
But since ye dare provoke me to be foolish—

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: She has, yes, and too worthie of your usage,
Before the world, I justifie her goodnes,
And turne that man, that dares but taint her vertues,
To my Swords point; that lying man, that base man,
Turne him, but face to face, that I may know him

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What have I here?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: A Gentleman, a free man,
One that made triall of this Ladies constancie,
And found it strong as fate; Leave off your fooling,
For if you follow this course, you will be Chronicled
For a devill, whilst a Saint she is mentioned,
You know my name indeed; I am now no Lawyer.
Some comfort now, I hope, or els would I wer hanged up

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: And yet the Judge, he makes me swet.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What newes now?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: I will justifie upon my life, and Credit
What you have heard, for truth, and will make prooffe of

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: I will be ready at the appointed hower there,
And so I leave ye.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Stay I beseech your worship,
And doe but heare me,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Good Sir, intend this busines,
And let this bawling Foole; No more words Lawyer,
And no more angers, for I guesse your reasons,
This Gentleman, I'l justifie in all places,
And that faire Ladies worth; Let who dare crosse it,
The Plot was cast by me, to make thee jealous,
But not to wrong your wife, she is faire and vertuous,

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Take us to mercy too, we beseech your honour,
We shall be justified the way of all flesh els,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: No more talke, nor no more dissention Lawyer,
I know your anger, 'tis a vaine and slight one,
For if you doe; I'll lay your whole life open
A life that all the world shall I'll bring witnes,
And rip before a Judge the ulcerous villanies
You know I know ye, and I can bring witnes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nay good Sir, noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Be at peace then presently,
Immediately take honest and faire truce
With your good Wife, and shake hands with that Gentleman;
Has honour'd ye too much, and doe it cheerefully,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Take us along, for heaven sake too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am Friends,
There is no remedie, I must put up all,
And like my neighbours rub it ou't by'th shoulders,
And perfect friends; Leandro now I thanke ye,
And ther's my hand, I have no more grudge to ye,
But I am too meane henceforward for your Companie,

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: I shall not trouble ye,

sp.speaker: Ars.
sp.l: We will be friends too:

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Nay Lawyer, you shall not fright us farther,
For all your devills wee will bolt,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I grant ye.
The Gentleman's your Baile and thank his comming,
Did not he know me too well, you should smart for't;
Goe all in peace, but when ye Foole next, Gentlemen,
Come not to me to Breakefast.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I'l be bak'd first.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And pray ye remember, when ye are bold & merry,
The Lawyers Bancket, and the Sawce he gave ye,

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Come: goe along; I have employment for ye,
Employment for your lewd braynes too, to coole ye.
For all, for every one.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are all your Servants.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: All, all for any thing, from this day forward,
I'l hate all Breakefasts, and depend on dinners

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: I am glad you come off faire

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: The faire has blest me.

div.head: Scena Tertia.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: This is the place, but why we are appointed
By Don Iami to stay here, is a depth
I cannot sound,

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Beleev't he is too noble,
To purpose any thing but for our good
Had I assurance of a thousand Lives,
And with them perpetuitie of pleasure,
And should loose all, if he prov'd only false,
Yet I durst run the hazard,

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: 'Tis our comfort,
We cannot be more wretched then we are,
And death concludes all misery,

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Undiscovered
We must attend him

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Our stay is not long
With him Don Henrique?

sp.speaker: Iac.
sp.l: Now I feare;
Be silent.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Why do'st thou follow me?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: To save your life,
A plot is laid for't, all my wrongs forgot,
I have a Brothers Love,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: But thy false self,
I feare no enemy.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: You have no Friend,
But what breathes in me: If you move a step
Beyond this ground you tread on: you are lost.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: 'Tis by thy practise then: I am sent hither
To meete her, that prefers my life, and safetie
Before her owne.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: That you should be abus'd thus
With weake credulitie: She for whose sake,
You have forgot we had one noble Father,
Or that one Mother bare us, for whose love,
You breake a contract, to which heaven was witnes,
To satisfie whose pride, and willfull humour,
You have expos'd a sweet, and hopefull Son,
To all the miseries, that want can bring him,
And such a Son, though you are most obdurate,
To give whom entertainement Savages
Would quit their Caves themselves, to keepe him from
Bleake cold, and hunger: This dissembling Woman,
This Idoll, whom you worship: all your love
And service trod under her feete, designes you
To fill a grave or dead, to lye a pray,
For Wolues, and vultures.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: 'Tis false; I defie thee,
And stand upon my Guard

div.stage: Enter Leandro Millanes, Arsenio, Bart. Lopez, Deigo, Octavio Iacinta Ascanio and Servants.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Alas, 'tis weake:
Come on, since you will teach me to be cruell,
By having no faith, in me, take your fortune,
Bring the rest forth, and bind them fast.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: In what have we offended?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: I am deafe,
And following my will, I doe not stand
Accomptable to reason: See her Ring
(The first pledge of your love, and service to her)
Deliverd as a Warrant for your death:
These Bags of gold you gave up to her trust,
(The use of which, you did deny your selfe)
Bestow'd on me, and with a prodigall hand,
Whom she pick'd forth to be the Architect
Of her most bloudy building; and to Fee
These Instruments, to bring Materials
To raise it up, she bad me spare no cost,
And (as a surplusage) offer'd her selfe
To be at my devotion.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: O accurss'd!

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: But be incredulous still; think this my plot;
Fashion excuses to your selfe, and sweare
That she is innocent, that she doats on ye;
Believe this, as a fearefull Dreame, and that
You Ile not at my mercy, which in this
I will shew onely: She her selfe shall give
The dreadfull Sentence, to remove all scruple
Who 'tis that sends you to the other world.
Appeares my Violante? speake (my dearest)
Do's not the object please you?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: More then if
All Treasure that's above the earth, with that,
That lyes conceal'd in both the Indian Mines,
Were laid downe at my feet: O bold Iamy
Thou onely canst deserve me.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: I am forward,
And (as you easily may perceive,) I sleepe not
On your commands.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But yet they live: I look'd
To find them dead.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: That was defer'd, that you
Might triumph in their misery, and have the powre
To say they are not,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Twas well thought upon:
This kisse, and all the pleasures of my Bed
This night, shall thanke thee.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Monster!

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You Sir, that
Would have me mother Bastards, being unable
To honour me with one Child of mine owne,
That underneath my Roofe, kept your cast-Strumpet,
And out of my Revenues, would maintaine
Her riotous issue: Now you find what 'tis
To tempt a woman: with as little feeling
As I turne off a slave, that is unfit
To doe me service; or a horse, or dog
That have out-liv'd their use, I shake thee off,
To make thy peace with heaven.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I doe deserve this,
And never truly felt before, what sorrow
Attends on wilfull dotage.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: For you, Mistris,
That had the pleasure of his youth before me,
And triumph'd in the fruit, that you had by him,
But that I thinke, to have the Bastard strangled
Before thy face, and thou with speed to follow
The way he leades thee, is sufficient torture,
I would cut off thy nose, put out thine eyes,
And set my foot on these bewitching lips,
That had the start of mine: but as thou art,
Goe to the grave unpittied.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Who would beleeve
Such rage could be in woman?

sp.speaker: Viol.,
sp.l: For this Fellow,
He is not worth my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Let him live then,
Since you esteeme him innocent.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: No, Iamy,
He shall make up the messe: now strike together
And let them fall so.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Unheard of crueltie
I can endure no longer: seize on her.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Am I betraid?
Is this thy faith, Iamy?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Could your desires
Challenge performance of a deed so horrid?
Or, though that you had sold your selfe to hell,
I should make up the bargaine? Live (deare Brother)
Live long, and happy: I forgive you freely;
To have done you this service, is to me
A faire Inheritance: And how e're harsh language
(Call'd on, by your rough usage) pass'd my lipps,
In my heart, I ever lov'd you: All my labours
Were but to shew, how much your love was cozen'd,
When it beheld it selfe in this false Glasse,
That did abuse you; and I am so far
From envying young Ascanio his good fortune,
That if your State were mine, I would adopt him.
These are the Murtherers my noble Friends,
Which (to make triall of her bloudy purpose)
I won, to come disguis'd thus.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I am too full
Of griefe, and shame to speake: but what I'le doe,
Shall to the world proclaime my penitence;
And howsoever I have liv'd, I'le die
A much chang'd man.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Were it but possible
You could make satisfaction to this woman,
Our joyes were perfect.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: That's my onely comfort,
That it is in my power: I ne're was married
To this bad woman, though I doted on her,
But daily did deferre it still expecting
When griefe would kill Iacintha.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: All is come out,
And finds a faire successe: take her Don Henrique,
And once againe embrace your Son.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Most gladly.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Your Brother hath deserv'd well.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: And shall share
The moitie of my State,

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: I have heard, Advocate,
What an ill Instrument you have bin to him,
From this time strengthen him, with honest counsells,
As you'le deserve my pardon.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'le change my Copy:
But I am punish'd, for I feare I have had
A smart blow, though unseene.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: Curat, and Sexton,
I have heard of you too, let me heare no more,
And what's past, is forgotten; For this woman,
Though her intent were bloody, yet our Law
Calls it not death: yet that her punishment
May deter others from such bad attempts,
The Dowry she brought with her shall be emploi'd
To build a Nunnery, where she shall spend
The remnant of her life.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Since I have miss'd my ends,
I scorne what can fall on me.

sp.speaker: Assist.
sp.l: The strict discipline
Of the Church, will teach you better thoughts. And Signiors.
You that are Batchelours, if you ever marry,
In Bartolus, you may behold the issue
Of Covetousnesse, and Jealousie; And of dotage,
And falshood in Don Henrique keep a meane then;
For be assur'd that weake man meets all ill,
That gives himselfe up to a womans will. Exeunt.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: TO tell ye (Gentlemen,) we have a Play,
A new one too, and that 'tis launch'd to day,
The Name ye know, that's nothing to my Story;
To tell ye, 'tis familiar, void of Glory;
Of State, of Bitternesse: of wit you'll say,
For that is now held wit, that tends that way,
Which we avoid: To tell ye to 'tis merry,
And meant to make ye pleasant, and not weary:
The Streame that guides ye, easie to attend:
To tell ye that 'tis good, is to no end,
If you believe not. Nay, to goe thus far,
To sweare it, if you sweare against, is war
To assure you any thing, unlesse you see,
And so conceive, is vanity in me;
Therefore I leave it to it selfe, and pray
Like a good Barke, it may worke out to day,
And stem all doubts; 'twas built for such a proofe,
And we hope highly: if she lye aloofe
For her owne vantage, to give wind at will,
Why let her worke, onely be you but still,
And sweet opinion'd, and we are bound to say,
You are worthy Judges, and you crowne the Play.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: THe Play is done, yet our Suit never ends,
Still when you part, you would stil part our friends,
Our noblest friends; if ought have falne amis,
O let it be sufficient, that it is,
And you have pardon'd it. In Buildings great
All the whole Body, cannot be so neat,
But something may be mended; Those are faire,
And worthy love, that may destroy, but spare.
